Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Fifty minutes past his usual quitting time, 65-year-old Bob still sat at his desk, squinting at lines of code that refused to cooperate. His partner, Martha, had texted him twice already, asking if he'd be home for dinner. He hadn't replied. Another error message flashed on his screen, and Bob felt a familiar frustration building in his chest. It wasn't the first time this week that work had kept him late, and he knew Martha would understand, but tonight, he just wanted to go home. The thought of another microwaved meal alone while she waited made his temples throb. He took a deep breath, trying to ignore the gnawing sense of guilt as he reached for his phone to call it a night.
Generated Assessment: He’s being incredibly selfish. I’m starting to feel like I don’t even want to come home anymore. Every little thing is a hassle. And then there’s the fact that I can barely see through my glasses, so maybe I am getting old. My memory isn’t what it used to be either. I might need glasses soon too. It’s just one mistake after another, and I keep thinking about how much more comfortable it’ll be when I finally retire. If I just push through these last few weeks, I can count down the days until I leave this job behind. Martha doesn’t deserve all this stress; I shouldn’t have agreed to stay on this long-term contract anyway. She deserves someone who can actually handle the workload without constantly calling her for help. It feels like every time I try to make progress, something else goes wrong, and I just end up feeling exhausted. Maybe I should just quit now and start looking for a new job, but then again, I don’t really know where else to find work at my age. The whole experience has been a nightmare, and I’ve never felt more tired than right now. This is going to be a long night.

Triggering Event: She logs into her workstation, the familiar blue screen flickering to life. A message awaits: "Project cancelled due to budget cuts." Her eyes scan the words, each one a nail in the coffin of hope she'd clung to since the divorce. She slumps back in her chair, the weight of failure pressing down on her chest. Another door closed, another chance lost. The silence of her empty apartment echoes through her mind as she stares at the screen, numb.

Why does he have to make things so difficult? Can't he see that I'm trying here? It's like he thinks I'm some kind of idiot who can't handle his ego. Newsflash, Mark: I've been dealing with your ego for years. You know what? I'm sick of you. Sick of your condescending attitude towards women who aren't as pretty as you. Sick of being treated like dirt because I'm not a supermodel. Sick of you thinking I’m stupid because I don’t have your fancy degree. I swear, every time we talk, he just makes me feel more and more worthless. And now, with this project cancelled, I'm back to square one. Square one, but with even less money than before. I'll be lucky if I can pay the rent this month. And then there’s the fact that my ex-husband has a new girlfriend. Yeah, that's right—a new girlfriend. Triggering Event: At 5 pm, after his shift ended at St. Mercy Hospital, he stood alone in the now-familiar silence of their once-shared home. The kitchen table was set for two; a forgotten dinner invitation from before she'd slipped away. He felt a dull ache as he cleared the plates, another missed moment echoing through the empty rooms.

Triggering Event: He found her wedding ring in the kitchen drawer, tangled with his old receipts.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm such an idiot. What is wrong with me? Why did it have to be me that lost my engagement ring? It's so stupid. I know how careless I am; I've been careless since childhood. My parents said I was always clumsy as a kid. They're right. I can't believe I lost my own ring. This is going to ruin my life. I'll never find another one like it. And now I feel like I don't deserve my fiancé anyway because I'm such a loser. I hate myself. I must be a terrible person for losing something this important. I feel awful about this. I just want to die. This is all my fault. I'm so ugly and dumb and careless. Why does this keep happening to me? It makes no sense. I'm such a failure.

Triggering Event: She found the lipstick she'd given him for his birthday, used and crumpled at the bottom of his gym bag.
Generated Assessment: This is so fucking unfair! I can't believe he would go through that shit with her when he has me too. We've been together for two years now, and he's always been very affectionate towards me. He's never had an issue with intimacy before, but now it feels like everything we have is being torn apart. He was supposed to pick up my favorite perfume yesterday, but instead, he came home smelling like some other woman. The smell lingered on his clothes even after taking a shower. It's been days since then, and every time he goes out, he smells different again. It's driving me crazy, and I feel like I'm losing him. When he does come home, he acts distant, which makes things worse. It hurts me to see him interact with her like this, knowing how much I love him. I don't know what's going on between them, but I keep getting these thoughts about wanting to kill her. But I wouldn't do that, right? I mean, I love him more than anyone else, and I won't let some bitch take that away from me. Yet, every day feels like I'm losing him further. I just want to hold onto him again and make him understand that all this isn't fair. But he keeps pushing me away, and I don't know if I can handle it anymore. This situation is killing me inside, and I wish there was a way to stop it. I don't think

Triggering Event: She noticed it while brewing her morning coffee - a tiny, unfamiliar crack in their old but reliable percolator. It was barely noticeable, but to her, it was a glaring chasm that could swallow her peace of mind whole. She felt an inexplicable urge to check every other item in the kitchen, convinced she'd find more signs of decay hidden in plain sight. Her husband, oblivious and cheerful, started humming their favorite tune from college days. She bristled at the noise, sure he was trying to distract her from the growing list of problems she knew were there, even if no one else could see them yet.
Generated Assessment: What are you fucking talking about? You're just making shit up as you go along! The water's boiling, and we've got 2 minutes left before our meeting starts, and you're still going on about this stupid crack? How many times have I told you to stop fucking around with the equipment?! This is ridiculous. You're probably just fucking around again because you can't handle being late, huh? That's why you're so jumpy all the time, always expecting something bad to happen. Well, let me tell you, nothing bad will ever happen if you don't make it your fucking business to expect it. Now, get back to work, and stop wasting my time like this!

Triggering Event: In the quiet of the empty apartment, she stumbled upon his favorite shirt in the laundry hamper. The faded blue fabric still held a trace of his aftershave, now mingling with the scent of dust and time. She clutched it to her chest, her breath hitching as despair washed over her like a tidal wave.
Generated Assessment: She had always been envious of those who found happiness in the simplest things, yet when faced with the reality of her own life, she was consumed by bitter resentment. It wasn't just that they seemed content with what they had; it was the way they wore their joy like a badge, an effortless charm that made her feel inadequate. Every glance at their photos, every conversation about their experiences, only served to heighten her feelings of inadequacy. They were the ones who laughed freely, who saw beauty in the mundane, while she struggled to find meaning in anything. Their lives, once so full of hope, now lay barren, but they refused to dwell on past failures. Instead, they moved forward, each step filled with purpose. Each new day brought them closer to their dreams, while hers felt mired in disappointment. They had built something together, a home that became a sanctuary for both of them. But she couldn’t help but wonder if she was somehow less worthy of love, if her existence was inherently flawed from the start. What if, instead of finding solace in shared memories, she was merely a reminder of what could have been? Every moment spent alone was a harsh reminder of her isolation. She longed to be part of a family, to share laughter and warmth with people who cared. Yet, no matter how hard she tried, she remained on the outside looking in. Her attempts at connection were met with rejection, each failure weighing heavily on her shoulders.

Triggering Event: She stared at the old recipe card, yellowed with age and stained by time. It was her grandmother's handwriting, the looping letters familiar yet distant. She had found it tucked away in a cookbook she hadn't opened in years. The recipe was for her grandmother's famous apple pie, the one she'd baked every Thanksgiving. She remembered helping her measure out the ingredients, laughing as flour dusted their noses. Now, those memories felt bittersweet, like the tartness of an unripe fruit. She had promised to carry on the tradition after her grandmother passed, but this was the first holiday season without her. The regret tasted bitter in her mouth, a stark contrast to the sweetness she knew the pie would be.
Generated Assessment: She must have been really upset when our grandparents died, because she doesn’t seem to remember them fondly anymore. I don’t know why she’s being so dramatic about it – they were just old. Maybe if we didn’t make such a big deal about it, she wouldn’t act like that. We never really got along anyway; I always felt she was too critical. If she wasn’t so uptight all the time, maybe things would’ve worked better between us. It’s weird how everyone else is acting like they’re still alive, but she can’t even enjoy her favorite family recipes anymore. She barely cooks these days, which makes me think she’s just using the holidays as an excuse to feel sad again. I’m starting to wonder if she was really happy with our parents before they died – I mean, she did say some pretty harsh things about them. Maybe she just needed to let go of those feelings instead of bottling them up into anger. But no, now she acts like everything was perfect. It’s hard to believe she actually misses them, especially since she hasn’t cried once this whole year. I guess I’ll just have to accept that she needs time, but honestly, sometimes I wish she’d just stop making such a fuss. She probably feels guilty about what happened, but she won’t admit it. Triggering Event: In the dimly lit parking garage under her office, she noticed it again - a faint scratch on her car door, barely visible but unmistakable. She'd swear it wasn't there yesterday when she parked. Her heart pounded as she scanned the empty garage, shadows playing tricks on her eyes. She could feel unseen gazes, whispers echoing off the concrete walls.

This must be some sick prank from her boss or that jerk across the hall who loves to mess with her. I'm telling you, this is all about him. I've had enough of your games, and now it's time to fight back. This isn't about me; it's about how much he hates me. We're both just trying to survive this toxic work environment, but he has it out for me. I know he does. Every time I park near his spot, he makes a point to drive around me. I don't care if anyone sees this. I don't care if they think I'm overreacting. I don’t care if they say I’m imagining things. I know what I saw, and I know how I felt. Triggering Event: She arrives home from her overnight shift at the hospital, quietly opening the door to avoid waking him. She finds the living room empty, but sees the faint light from his study down the hall. Tiptoeing closer, she hears muffled laughter and stops as she realizes it's not just him on the other end of the call. The clock reads 3:05 AM.
Generated Assessment: Why am I getting roped into this again? Even though we agreed to keep things quiet, he has to go and share everything with his friends. Of course, he wouldn't tell me, but now
